title: WCAS ASTRON 390-0-1 Current Topics in Astronomy

instructors.instructor_addr: Technological Institute Building (2145 Sheridan Road), Room F-215, Evanston

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Before 1931, the study of the universe was limited to optical observations of the
night sky. Karl Jansky working at Bell Labs in New Jersey, changed everything by
building a radio telescope that could observe the sky 24/7. This course surveys
basics of radio astronomical techniques and advances that have been made since
Jansky discovered radio emission from our Galaxy. We will discuss technical aspects
of antenna theory, interferometers, signal processing and astronomical discoveries
that have been made at radio wavelengths ranging between millimeters and meters. We
will explain the mechanisms (e.g., synchrotron, thermal, masers) responsible for
producing radio emission from stars, pulsars, supernova remnants, our Milky Way
Galaxy and radio galaxies.
